nodes.text: Economic decision-making and market dynamics can be modeled using a quantum-inspired propensity framework in which propensity functions, expressed in quantum probability terms, replace classical utility and yield a consistent dynamical theory of transactions

Quantum probability, based on the 2-norm and complex amplitudes, naturally models superposition, interference, and entanglement observed in human decision behavior that classical probability cannot capture
A simple two-qubit quantum circuit with rotation gates and a C-NOT can simulate cognitive phenomena such as the order effect, disjunction effect, preference reversal, and forms of social entanglement

A propensity function over continuous economic variables (e.g., price) can be interpreted as the squared amplitude of an underlying quantum wave function, yielding a mapping from observed probabilities to quantum states

Coupling the propensity framework with entropic forces and a quantum oscillator analogy provides consistent units and dynamics for economic quantities, including an information-linked energy and a notion of economic mass and frequency

Quantum probability properties (nonadditivity, noncommutativity) explain cognitive anomalies like order effects and disjunction effects documented in empirical studies better than classical utility models
The two-qubit circuit operation psi_f = Xc (A tensor B) psi0 reproduces the joint probabilities for sequential yes/no question responses given by a projection sequence formulation

Interpreting gate A as context and gate B as decision or utility allows the same circuit to simulate the disjunction effect, preference reversal, and strategic interactions like a version of the prisoner s dilemma
For a normal propensity P(x) with mean mu and standard deviation sigma, the entropic force F(x) = gamma P'(x)/P(x) reduces to a linear spring-like force F(x) = -k(x-mu) with k = gamma / sigma squared

The quantum harmonic oscillator ground state corresponds to a normal propensity curve and implies an associated economic mass m = hbar / (2 omega sigma squared) so mass varies inversely with propensity variance

The information or work required to change propensity between states x1 and x2 is Delta E = gamma log( P(x2)/P(x1) ), linking propensity changes to an energy measure; a typical preference reversal factor of about 3 corresponds to base oscillator energy ~ hbar omega / 2
Frequency omega can be interpreted as a linearized resistance to change or mean reversion speed in economic contexts, giving a temporal scale analogous to thermalization time in physics

Threshold effects arise because random context-dependent subjective factors (gate A) can switch like a step, producing abrupt preference reversals when objective costs satisfy a criterion roughly x2/x1 > 3, a result consistent with empirical tests

The quantum propensity framework can be applied to economic and financial problems including modeling supply and demand dynamics, pricing and volume of financial options, and statistical features of market returns

Advantages of the quantum propensity approach include incorporating cognitive interference and entanglement, providing consistent units for economic forces, and treating subjective and objective factors symmetrically
